rule.title: Malicious Script Execution via PowerShell
rule.description: Detects the execution of malicious scripts using PowerShell
falsepositives: Legitimate PowerShell scripts using the same domains for non-malicious purposes
Administrative tasks that involve downloading files from the specified domains

rule.description: Detects potential phishing attacks by identifying Office processes spawning command shells
falsepositives: Administrative tasks involving command shell execution

strengths: The rule is well-structured and follows the Sigma format
It targets a specific technique (Malicious Script) and uses relevant keywords in the detection logic
The rule includes a list of potential false positives, which can help with tuning and refinement
weaknesses: The rule contains a large number of hardcoded domains, which may not be comprehensive or up-to-date
The rule does not account for potential evasion techniques, such as code obfuscation or domain variation
The real-world verification result is not available, which makes it difficult to assess the rule's effectiveness
The rule contains domains not present in the TTP info, which could lead to hallucinations and false positives
suggestions: Implement a more dynamic approach to domain tracking, such as using threat intelligence feeds or machine learning-based anomaly detection
Add additional detection logic to account for evasion techniques and variations of the malicious script
Perform real-world verification to validate the rule's effectiveness and identify potential areas for improvement
Review and refine the list of hardcoded domains to ensure they are relevant and up-to-date
Consider adding more context to the rule, such as user or system information, to help reduce false positives and improve detection accuracy
